subdebate.1.para: Disputer Returns and Qualifications Committee's Report

question.para: Mr. President, I wish to direct your attention to an article in this morning's Argus, which is headed " Disputed Senate Seat," and sub-headed " Election Committee's Report." It says-—
question.quote: A draft report had been prepared by the chairman, and this was submitted to the Committee and considered. The greater portion of the report was adopted, and it was decided to defer further consideration until October
question.para: when Senator de Largie will have returned. I ask you, sir, whether, in your opinion, if is not advisable to bring the author of the report before the Senate and ascertain whe-. ther a breach of privilege has not been committed ; in fact, whether the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications has given a report to fhe press before it has been communicated to tbe Senate?

interjection.para: Why does not the honorable senator read the. article to the Senate?

continue.para: I will read the remainder of the paragraph—
continue.quote: This was done in order that the Committee, might, if possible, present a unanimous report to the Senate. The report will, it.is understood, upset the opinion of the Attorney-General that a casual vacancy had been created by the voiding of Mr. Vardon's election. The Committee will be unanimously of opinion that the selection should not have been made by the State Parliament, but that a fresh election by the people of South Australia should have been held. This will, of course, mean, if the report is adopted by the Senate, that Senator O'Loghlin will be unseated, and a new election held.
continue.para: I ask, sir, that the author of the paragraph should be made to divulge the source of his information. When a paragraph of that character is published in the press I think that a gross breach of the privileges of the Senate is committed.
Is the honorable senator asking a question or raising a matter of privilege?
I am asking you, sir, to investigate the matter and report to the Senate whether a breach of privilege has been committed or not.

interjection.para: That is not the duty of the President.
What did the Age say last week?

continue.para: I do not know what the Age said last week. I only know what the Argus says to-day.
Mr. President, I call your attention to the paragraph, and ask you whether you do not think that a breach of privilege has been committed, and what steps you will take in the matter?

answer.quote: The evidence taken by any Select Committee of the Senate, and documents presented to such Committee which have not been reported to the Senate, shall not be disclosed or published by any member, of such Committee, or by any other person.
answer.para: The honorable senator will observe that the report in the Argus is a statement that the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications met and determined to delay submitting their report until after a certain event had taken place. I do not see that the publication of that statement is a breach of privilege. The report goes on with an assumption by the writer that such and such a thing will be the case. Unless the honorable senator is in a position to show that a breach of privilege - has been committed by a member of the Committee, it is difficult to proceed. I suggest that the attention of the chairman of the Committee should be directed to the paragraph, and also to standing order 296, and that he should ask whether a breach of that rule has been committed by any member of the Committee. The chairman would then be able to make an inquiry, and whan the result was reported the Senate would be in a position to take such action as it might be advised, or might deem it advisable, to take. At the present time, it has only a mere rumour or suggestion by a newspaper writer before it. I do not think that we can interfere with a newspaper suggesting anything it likes in that way. The standing order dealing with newspapers says—
answer.quote: Any senator complaining to the Senate of a statement in a newspaper as a breach of privilege,' shall produce a copy of the paper containing . the statement in question, and be prepared to give the. name of the printer or publisher, and also submit a substantive motion declaring the person in question to have been guilty of contempt.
answer.para: The honorable senator will see that even that does not affect the position very mucn. because it is only a suggestion by a newspaper that it is understood that so-and-so will take place. In all the circumstances, the only course which I think the Senate can very well take is to cause an inquiry to be made of the Committee, througb its chairman1, as to whether any information has been divulged and in the way suggested, and then to take whatever action it may see fit.

continue.para: I cannot put a question directly to the chairman of the Committee, because he is not in his place this morning.

question.para: I call the attention of Senator Dobson to the statement made in the Argus this morning, that—
question.quote: A draft report had been prepared by the chairman, and this was submitted to the Committee and considered. The greater portion of the report was adopted, and it was decided to defer further consideration until October 3, when Senator de Largie will have returned.
question.para: I ask the honorable senator if that is a true statement of what took place?

interjection.para: The honorable senator can only ask Senator Dobson if he has communicated it to the newspaper.

continue.para: No; I ask the honorable senator if it is a true statement of what took place at the meeting of the Committee?

answer.para: I would point out to the honorable senator 'that the report, so far as he has gone, is not of great moment to the Senate. It is a matter of public notoriety that the Committee has been sitting and inquiring into this case. The mere publication of the statement that the Committee had met, that a report had been drafted, and that final consideration of it had been postponed until a certain event is surely no breach of privilege. It is a mere statement of what has been done, and not a statement of the conclusions arrived at or of the nature of the report to be made to the Senate. If any attempt were made by a member of the Committee to inform the press that its report would contain sb-and-so, it would certainly be a serious breach of privilege, and also a breach of duty on his part.

question.para: I ask Senator Dobson if anv authority was granted to any. member of the Committee to supply to the press a report of its proceedings?

May I ask, sir, whether, in the remarks you have just made, you assume that there is no technical difference between the Committee of Disputed Returns and Elections and a Select Committee, to which the standing order you read specifically refers?

answer.para: In a matter of this character I think there should be no difference. I understand that an application was made to the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications that representatives of the press should be allowed to be present during the inquiry. The public have not been admitted, and therefore no information could have been obtained in that way. I think that the standing order I quoted will, so far as it goes, apply to the case of an inquiry into a disputed return.

debate.speech: In Committee (Consideration resumed from 19th September, vide page 3493): First Schedule— Rubber; (period) 15 years; (rate of bounty). 10 per cent, on market value; (maximum amount payable in any one year) 2,000.

(Tasmania—Minister of Home Affairs) [10.48].—When progress was reported yesterday, I was addressing myself to this item, and dealing with the arguments advanced to induce the Committee to refrain from granting the bounty. As I then pointed out, the main argument is that Papua, a territory of the Commonwealth, and other islands in the Pacific, in respect of which we have some interest, are preeminently adapted for the production of rubber. I think honorable senators can rest assured that parts of Australia, including Northern Queensland, and especially the Northern Territory, • are also preeminently adapted for the production of this article. I said yesterday that, while we wished nothing but good luck to Papua in its development, the fact that it is preeminently adapted for the production of rubber is no reason why our own people should not turn their attention to the growth of this article, which has a growing demand in the world's market. I referred to the great expansion of the demand for rubber, illustrating my remarks in that connexion by a reference to the imports to Great Britain in 1830, and for different periods , up to date. I mentioned, further, that up to a comparatively recent period the world's supply of this article was dependent mainly upon " wild " rubber. Recently plantation rubber has come into existence, and, although it so far forms but a small portion of the world's total output of rubber, its success has been demonstrated beyond alb possible doubt. When dealing with this aspect of the question I referred to the fact that rubber had been planted with success in what is called the Middle East, and quoted from an article which appeared in the Melbourne Argus in August last, a reference to the opposition, which those who proposed planting rubber in the Middle East had to meet. I point out that the statements and conclusions stated in the article contributed by "L.T.C." to the Melbourne Argus of ioth August have so far as I know met with no hostile criticism.

speech.para: The honorable senator does not suppose that we have time to answer every anonymous letter that appears in the newspapers.
The honorable senator does not suppose that we have time to answer every anonymous letter that appears in the newspapers.

am aware that Senator Chataway has not the time to do so, but there are many people deeply interested in these matters who have the inclination and the time. If they have any information on such subjects they are usually very glad to furnish it to the press, and especially if by doing so they can controvert the published statements of some one else.
Does the Minister attach very much importance to the letters which have appeared in the press on the subject of the Tariff?

Letters from anonymous correspondents are daily appearing in the press, but so far as I know the statements in the contributed article to which I refer have remained unchallenged, and I leave honorable senators to appreciate that fact at its proper value. The writer of the article after speaking of the profits of the industry says—
speech.quote: These figures may appear to be unduly optimistic, but we are told by those who know that " pioneers of the movement who, when they first began planting Para rubber in the Middle East, a comparatively few years ago, were regarded as cranks or laughed at as visionaries, are being rewarded for their enterprise and foresight with profits which might well make many a successful gold-miner envious." According to a statement in one of the Malayan newspapers, 13,322 lb. of dry rubber was obtained in 1905 from 10,453 s'x to seven year old trees on the West Country Estate, while the same trees have yeilded 16,300 Ib. during six months 1906
speech.para: Reference is also made to the reasons for the increasing demand for rubber. It is being used for a large variety of purposes, and although chemists during a considerable period have devoted their attention to the discovery of some synthetic substitute their efforts so far have not been crowned with anything in the nature of success. It was suggested some time ago that a synthetic substitute for rubber might be obtained from wheat.
The experts in their report affirm that that has been done

No, they say that it was claimed that a synthetic substitute had been found, the basis of which was wheat, but it was not a success. There are other natural products for which synthetic substitutes have been sought by chemists, but that fact has not deterred indi viduals from investing their money in the production of those articles. Referring to the price of rubber the writer of the article speaks of the increased demand which would be created by a reduction in the present price. He writes—
speech.quote: In view of the facts just cited and the probability of a multiplication of plantations taking place in the near future, a very natural question arises, viz., "Will not the supply largely ex-ceed the demand in a few years?" All the probabilities are in the opposite direction. Conditional on tlie price of rubber remaining as ai present, viz., 5s. 9d. per lb. (Para); it is almost certain that the 10 per cent, annual increase in the consumption which has been maintained for some years past, will be but barely met by the world's supply for at least eight years to come.
speech.para: He gives reasons in support of that opinion, and continues—
speech.quote: The managing director of one of the most extensive English rubber manufacturing companies expressed the opinion recently that a drop in the price of rubber to 4s. per lb. would double the demand, and if it went as low as 3s. the demand would be quadrupled. This can be easily understood.
speech.para: He enumerates some of the purposes for which rubber is used, and says—
speech.quote: For electrical, dental, motor, cycle, and other purposes rubber must be had at any cost, whilst a fall in price of 20 per cent, would bring about its general use for floor-coverings, foot-walks, and even road-paving.
speech.para: In London, and possibly elsewhere, rubber has been used for pavements with excellent results. After a test of many years of comparatively heavy traffic it has been found that the durability of rubber pavements far exceeds that of wood, though, of course, its cost is greater. Its relative durability more than balances the increased cost. The writer of the article continues—
speech.quote: It will be a matter for surprise to many to learn that the rubber road laid in 1881 under the archway leading to Euston station was found to have only worn down to five-eighths of an inch in the thinnest places after 21 years' constant use. Whilst its initial cost was something under three times as much as wood or asphalt, it had a life of 20 years as against a life of four years.
speech.para: Honorable senators must see what an important bearing this has upon the possible demand for rubber in the world's market. It cannot have escaped the attention of any member of the Committee that every year rubber is being more diversely, as well as more extensively used. So far as the use of rubber for paving is concerned there can be no doubt that if it could be supplied at something below the present price of 5s: 9d. per lb. for para rubber, it would be extensively used for this purpose.
Where does the honorable senator get that price from?
I am quoting from the article to which I have referred.
The Minister's official document gives the price as from 4s. to 5s. per lb.

The quotation I have already made from the article refers to the price as 5s. 9d. per lb., and the writer says _ that if the price could be brought down to 4s. the demand for rubber, as compared with the existing demand at 5s. 9d. per Ib., would be perhaps quadrupled, whilst if the price could be cut down to something like 3s. the demand would be immensely multiplied. It is easy to understand that if it could be economically used for the purpose of street paving and the flooring of houses, there would be an immense future before the rubber industry. It is possible that it will yet solve one of the difficulties which confronts the City Council of Melbourne and other large cities in Australia. In all the circumstances honorable senators must admit that it is advisable that we should take some steps to secure the cultivation of rubber in the Commonwealth. A few years ago it would have probably been out of the question to submit such a proposal, because the answer would have been that) rubber grew in a wild natural state, and it would be absurd to try to compete against it. But during the last few years experience has shown that plantation rubber can be produced in competition with natural rubber. It is now being grown in increasing quantities. The bounty proposed is not very much, and we believe that it will induce people to enter into the cultivation of this product in the Northern Territory and elsewhere. I know that my honorable friend, Senator Dobson, is very anxious that something should be done for the Northern Territory, but we need not wait for the formal acquisition of the Territory by the Commonwealth. It is already part and parcel of the Commonwealth, and if any rubber is grown in the Northern Territory no matter whether the agreement that has been tentatively entered into is adopted by Parliament or not, the growers will be eligible for the bounty
I believe that land cannot be taken up there now.

Land has already been taken up. and probably much of it could be devoted to rubber cultivation. I understand that there are already some natural rubber trees in the Northern Territory, but they are not so good as the trees that grow in other parts of the world, notably in South America. We can well hold out this little encouragement to those who turn their attention to the growth of rubber, either in the Northern Territory or in any other part of Australia. Although it may be grown in Papua as well, we shall have'the satisfaction of knowing that our own people in Australia are doing what they can to make the industry a success. In Papua rubber cultivation, as we all recognise, will largely depend upon native laoour. The labour there is somewhat precarious, and if we have to depend entirely upon it nothing may be done in the growth of rubber for many years to come. If rubber is grown in Papua at all, it will be grown largely by white labour; and both Papuan and Australian growers will assist in supplying the world's market. I draw attention to another article which was published on the 9th July, in the Melbourne Age, on the same subject. It states that—
speech.quote: It is estimated that since 1901 the area under rubber in Ceylon has increased from 2,500 acres to 120,000 acres to-day.
speech.para: The article also states—
speech.quote: As there has been a considerable development of a similar character in the Malay States and adjacent islands. A few authorities hold that there is some risk of over-production, taking into consideration the supplies of wild rubber available in South and Central America. On the other hand, the uses to which rubber can be applied are so multiplying yearly that other authorities think that there will be a profitable demand for all the rubber produced for many years to come.
speech.para: It says likewise—
speech.quote: Already rubber is coming into favour for paving purposes, and the expansion of its use for tyres minimises any risk of over-production.
speech.para: Recognising what an important product rubber is going to be in the 'future if we have any land in Australia suitable for its production, our people should be encouraged to devote their attention to it. They are not likely to give their attention to rubber cultivation without the stimulus of a bounty.
Because they do not believe in the facts which the Minister has cited.

There is a disposition, as my honorable friend knows—. because he is an apostle of it—on the part of some people not to move out of old ruts. People who have been growing wheat for years, and find themselves severely affected by competition from others who can grow it much more profitably, often refuse to turn their attention to oats or any other product, simply because their fathers, and their grandfathers before them, grew wheat. My honorable friend knows as many instances of that disposition as I do, and I know a good many. Many people are indisposed to turn to the production of anything that is new, unless they see the prospect of an immediate return, and unless all risk of loss is eliminated. Those who enter into rubber production have to wait for six or seven years before they begin to extract the latex from the trees. People who have not command of a considerable amount of capital would not be likely to turn their attention to it without the stimulus of a bounty, lest they should lose the immediate profit, small though it may be, from some other kind of production with which they have been associated for years.
(Tasmania) [11.9].— I am getting heartily sick of this Bounties Bill, and am tired of listening to the same sort of argument in favour of every item.
What about those honorable senators who have to listen?
he honorable senator need not listen unless he likes. There is the door.
Sheer weariness prevents some of us even from walking so far.

My honorable friend, Senator Keating, tells me that I know of some farmers who go on planting the same crops year after year, and who will not make a change unless they see a prospect of a large profit. Has not the honorable senator been devoting himself for the last half-hour to showing how large the profit from the cultivation of rubber is likely to be? H'e tells us that i f we have land and climate suitable for the growth of the rubber tree, rubber is a most profitable thing to produce. But there is much virtue in an "if." My honorable friend has turned away from the memorandum of the experts just when we have reached one or two items regarding which I should have liked him to devote some attention to it. Why did he not tell" us what the experts had to say about rubber? They say, for instance—
speech.quote: That this valuable tree will thrive in our northern latitudes is well known, although it is more than probable that New Guinea will prove a better home for it.
speech.para: They also tell us that it has been grown at a State nursery in Queensland—
speech.quote: The Director of the State Nursery at Kanerunga,- Cairns, has made very successful experiments with para rubber, and has distributed many plants and seeds in the northern portion of the State. But these will take time to come to the tapping stage.
speech.para: We do not therefore know yet whether the product of the trees will be the stuff that is wanted. How, therefore, can we beliteVe in the practicability orHow can we have a successful experiment, unless we test the value of the product and know whether it is of the right quality? But the Government are very anxious to. pose before the Commonwealth as a great protectionist Ministry. They are not content with their iniquitous Tariff, but must also submit an iniquitous Bounties Bill tosupport it. I should like to know whether any attempt has been made in any part of the Commonwealth to ascertain whether we have suitable soil and climate for the production of rubber. The whole thing is absolutely new. ' We ought to wait until the experiments have been concluded before we think of granting a bounty. If we adopt the experts' opinion, we ought undoubtedly to strike out the item. My honorable friend says that, notwithstanding that rubber can be grown in Papua, we ought to encourage our own people to grow it in- Australia. But we now have the Papuan- Territory on our hands, and we know that it is a most difficult task to make a success of it, owing to the scarcity of labour. Mr; Staniforth Smith is devoting himself to this subject. We all remember the admirable speeches which he made about developing industries in Papua while he was a member of the Sennte. He is now applying his great energies to making a success of rubber-growing, and why should we endeavour to make his task more difficult? We are actually going to spend -£30,000 to induce men to compete in the Commonwealth against our brothers in Papua. In that country, there is an enormous amount of native labour which is cheap, and there is suitable land for rubber cultivation.
How can the labour be called cheap if the men will not work?

DOBSON.—I am sorry to hear Senator Trenwith confirm Senator Keatinrr's pessimistic view that the 500,000 natives in Papua are useless. They are of good physique, intelligent, and splendid fighters. Mr. Staniforth Smith is going to train them as policemen and agriculturists. There may be some kink in their nature, but I have yet to learn that it is impossible to make agricultural labourers of them. Of course, I know what Senator Trenwith means, and I admit that I would radier pay a rood man ios. a day than a bad one 7s. or 8s.; but that argument does not apply to Papuan labour. I affirm that the labour of Papua is cheap. Wherever there are black men capable of working—and these are—the labour must be cheap compared with labour in the Commonwealth.' Considering Papua as indirectly part of the Commonwealth, and dealing with the whole Commonwealth as one, where is the best place to attempt to start this industry ? There is no spot in the Commonwealth as good as Papua for growing rubber. Papua is absolutely suitable for it, and Australia is not; while in Papua there is an abundance of cheap . labour. All that we ask is that a couple of items out of the whole seventeen should be kept back for the Northern Territory, and one left for Papua. We should not compete with our own people. Nobody could imagine the business-like Germans trying to grow a product in one of their Colonies, and at the same time giving a bounty to develop the same industry in the home country. Can anybody understand such folly? If it was our own money, would any one of us dare to spend a penny on such a Droject? The whole thing is monstrous. I wish honorable senators opposite would bear in mind the fact that we are trustees for the people's monev. They ought to have such facts before them, before they vote away public money, as would induce them to put their own money into the scheme. If every item in the -Bill was tested on that common- sense basis, not one of them would pass. The Minister read at some length letters which appeared in the Argus, and referred also to one that appeared in the Age. I understand that they were published early in July, at the time when Mr. Staniforth Smith was making) efforts to spread abroad the idea that Papua was exceedingly well suited for growing rubber, and pointing out that the pronts, i f the industry could be made a success, would be enormous. At that time about £10,000 had been sent from Victoria to Papua for investment in the industry, and, of course, all the letters that appeared at the time were favorable to the scheme. It reminds me of the fact that any one with plenty of go and talk and pluck can make out a case for a railway to anywhere.
If the honorable senator had listened- to me, he would have seen that the articles I quoted stressed the capabilities of Queensland and the Northern Territory, and not of Papua, for growing rubber.
It is all part of the same thing. We know perfectly well that Papua is more suitable, because the expert evidence is that a combination of elevation, moisture, and temperature are needed.
What elevation have they at Ceylon?
Ceylon is a most hilly place. Growing rubber in anv part of the Commonwealth is absolutely an experiment, and the experiment ought to precede the giving of a bounty.
(Victoria) [11.22]. —The fullest encouragement should be given to the growing of rubber in the Commonwealth.
It is only throwing money away.

Then nobody will be worse off than myself. Australia is essentially a protectionist nation, and a system of bounties is part of the system of protection. We should encourage by every means those industries which are natural to our country. Senator Keating produced expert evidence that rubber can be grown successfully in Northern Queensland and the Northern Territory. I find from the Customs returns that the importations into the Commonwealth last year amounted to ,£338,700, made up of £167,439 worth of manufactures, and £161,261 of crude rubber.
Would that be necessarily crude?
Not necessarily, but probably the greater portion qf it was.
The experts in their report say that there are no records available.

am informed, although not officially, that probably the £161,261 worth is rubber for manufacturing purposes. The fact that rubber and rubber goods to the value of £338J7P° were imported last j'ear into the Commonwealth shows that, rubber is extensively utilized here. Senator Dobson points out that certain experts are unanimous that Papua.-.is highly suitable for the cultivation of rubber. It is remarkable that the honorable senator accepts the opinion of the experts who reported on Papua, but declines to attach any weight to the opinions of the other experts who were appointed by the Government to report to Parliament about rubber and other items in this schedule. After all, as shown by the report of the Commission appointed to inquire into the affairs of Papua, and by Mr. Staniforth Smith's recent handbook, experts are at variance with regard to the rubber industry. The Commission gave an estimate, compiled on the figures supplied by a practical planter, of the cost of planting and maintaining a rubber plantation of 250 acres in Papua. They estimate the cost of felling and clearing at .£250. Mr. Smith, in his recent handbook, gives an estimate of .£375 for the same work. The Commission estimate the cost of living at ,£30, Mr. Smith at £M 10s.
And both are authorities?
I regard Mr. Smith as a better authority than some of the gentlemen who were on the Commission, because he has given considerable time, attention, and study to the question of tropical agriculture.
He would not know the cost of clearing an acre of ground if he saw it.

I think he would. He made two visits to Papua and one to parts of India. He made a close study of the questions on which he reports in his handbook. The Commission's and Mr. Smith's estimates continue as follow—
speech.quote: Commission. Mr. Smith. Nurseries ... ... £10 ... £50 o o Seed ... ... ... I0 ... y. 10 0 Planting ... ... J/ Roads and drains House for owner or superintendent Huts for natives Tools ... Medicine chest ... Contingencies ...
speech.para: Including the items I gave first, the total estimate of the Commission is ^£710, and that of Mr. Smith, which comprises other expenses, totals .£2,083 15s. Mr. Smith ?dds £i,°oo for the upkeep for five years, including labour, at £600 a year, making a total of £5,083 15s. He adds—.
speech.quote: If the area of plantation were doubled the total cost would be £8,276 ios., or £16 i0S. per acre up to the time of tapping, as items 9 and
speech.para: those are the items for supervision and house for superintendent—
speech.quote: would not be increased, while the upkeep would only be enhanced by 50 per cent.
speech.para: He goes on to say—
speech.quote: By skilful management catch crops between the trees might produce sufficient revenue, after the first two'or three years, to defray the cost of upkeep, reducing the capital outlay on a rubber plantation of 500 acres, up to time of tap-Ping> to £5>567> or £11 2s. 9d. per acre. Healthy well grown trees should each average 2 lbs. of rubber annually, which, at the-present price (5s. per lb.), would yield a gross income from 500 acres of £21,500, or over 250 per cent, per annum on the outlay, assuming that no catch crops were grown. Even if rubber dropped to 2s. per lb., the gross income would be over 100 per cent, per annum.

speech.para: It is obvious that he has gone wrong in his arithmetic.
I have not time to go into that matter.

If it is going to cost £16 ios. per acre to put the land under cultivation, and if each tree is going to yield 2 lbs. of rubber per year, and rubber is worth 5s. per pound, it is not a matter of 100 per cent., but of 1,000 per cent.

I will not argue that point with the honorable senator, because figures can be made to prove anything. The facts are that there is an increasing demand for rubber in every part of the world to-day, and that there is a tendency for the price of the article to go even higher than it has been within the last few months. Considering all the circumstances, I should say that the Committee ought not to hesitate to grant an annual bounty of .£2,000 for a period of fifteen years to encourage this industry.
On top of a 250 per cent, return.

The honorable senator know quite well that in his report Mr. Staniforth Smith is dealing with Papua, where labour is much cheaper than it is in any part of the Commonwealth. While it is true that it is difficult to get native labour in Papua, still the probability is that in the course of time, by kind treatment, the natives may be induced to work to the satisfaction of their employers. That experiment is being tried. I am not so much concerned about whether native labour in Papua will be satisfactory to the growers of rubber as I am about providing, as soon as possible, additional avenues of employment for the people of the Commonwealth. It is with a view to assist in-opening up new avenues of employment, and to attract population to Australia, that I think every item in the schedule is justifiable. I very much regret that the bounty for rubber is not larger than it is.
The honorable senator can propose an increase of the amount.

After yesterday's discussion, and the vote I gave in regard to rice, I am not disposed to move a request for an increase. It may be that we have the power, but having given a vote yesterday for what I considered to be the right course in connexion with rice, I do not intend to move for an increase in the case of this item. I hope that the Committee will give a stimulus to the industry, which, in my opinion, is deserving of every encouragement.

(Queensland) [rT.37].—The report of the Government experts on rubber is of such a peculiar character that I feel tempted to read it, but I shall spare the Committee, because it has been read in sections. This debate, in conjunction with the reports on this subject, reminds me very much of an incident of my school days. In the district near the school some wild berries used to grow. They had a rather acrid taste. Three or four of us were anxious to find out whether the berries might not be a sort of food. Others suggested that the berries had the reputation of being a dangerous kind of food, and that they might be poisonous. One infant philosopher said, ".We can easily settle that. We will try the berries on the dog, and if it does not harm the dog probably they will be all right." The proposition before the Committee is very much like such an experiment on the part of the Government. Practically, they say, " We do not know whether the bounty will do good. It can do harm, inasmuch as the money may be wasted, but we will try an experiment on the dog." I do not know that- that is a very wise course to pursue; certainly it is not economical.. I notice that Senator Findley, the Ministers, and others, who are ready to support every item in the schedule, are practically saying, "Let us try an experiment on tlie dog first." They plead that it will not cost much, and if the dog dies

interjection.para: It is somebody else's dog, anyhow.

speech.para: Yes. I can compliment the Minister and his supporters upon the very philosophical way in which they contemplate the making of an experiment on the dog.
The honorable senator is very unsympathetic towards an effort which is being made to establish the rubber industry in his State.

I am not aware that any effort of the kind is being made. I have looked through the various agricultural reports from the State, and I find that not one ounce of rubber has been produced there. Judging from the report of the Government experts, if there is one State in Australia which is favorable for the growth of rubber, probably it is Queensland. It comes next to Papua or the Northern Territory, but I do not know that its' people clamour for a raid to be made upon their pockets to promote the rubber industry. During the general election, I did not hear a reference made to the subject throughout the State. Our political opponents placarded the whole of the State with the most lavish promises of the enormous sums whicli, if they were returned, they would ask this Parliament to devote to the promotion of their agricultural industries. Fortunately, that fly did not catch. Although the promotion of agricultural industries was paraded before the electors, and although I think that a great many of them knew just as well as the experts—and the candidates—that, so far as climate and soil were concerned, rubber might be grown in some parts of the State, not a single demand was made during the campaign for a penny of public money to be put into the rubber industrj?. I think it is a fair inference that the people were of opinion that it was more "or less of a farce to propose that they should be raided in order to support an industry which no one demanded, and which, according to the report of the experts, would probably result in a howling failure.

(Queensland) [11.43]-—I do not know that there is any truth in the statement of Senator St. Ledger that during the general election Queensland was placarded from one end to the other with certain promises. I was in Queensland during the campaign, but I do not remember any statement having been, made by his political opponents that, if returned, they would get large sums of public mone\ expended in the various districts upon the promotion of tropical agriculture.
It was on the manifesto of the honorable senator's leader.

We hear very many statements from the honorable senator. It takes him nearly all his time to contradict his own statements. I do not see how he can expect others to believe him. During this debate, it has been pointed out that if there is one State in the Union which would benefit if the industry were established, it is Queensland. Senator St. Ledger has made that claim; consequently, in his opinion, Queensland is the dog. More experiments have been made, and more education has been imparted, on this subject, in that State than, in any other part of Australia. I feel quite satisfied that Senator St. Ledger does not know a great deal about the State which he represents. It has been urged by some honorable senators that a certain amount of agricultural education should be given before we attempted to sanction these bounties. For many years, education in tropical agriculture has been given in Queensland. At the Kamerunga State Farm, just outside Cairns, rubber trees have been planted, and have been in process of growth for a considerable time. There is not only a rubber plantation on the farm, but the authorities are distributing thousands of plants to people in Queensland, and also to people in Papua and in some of the islands in the Pacific. It is only quite recently that those in charge at Kamerunga have been able to overtake the demand for plants which has been made bpon the Agricultural Department. Information is given -regarding the cultivation of the plant, and also as to the area in Queensland which is suitable for its growth.
t is extraordinary that the people have never demanded a bounty.

It is not extraordinary that Senator St. Ledger has never heard of these things. The fact remains that a very large number of other people have heard of them, and some persons have cleared .ground and planted rubber trees. I have no doubt that up to the present Senator St. Ledger has never heard anything about it.
What I said was that the people have never asked for a bounty.

There are many products on which people do not ask for bounties, but when the honorable senator found that people were asking for a bounty on cotton, he was not prepared to oppose the grant of a bountv on that article.
Yes, the honorable senator did oppose it.

The honorable senator opposed everything in the Bill, at the commencement, but when he learned that the granting of a bounty for cotton might Ibe the means of doing a considerable amount of good, he was not prepared to carry his opposition to that item any further. Senator Dobson has.asked whether any experiments in rubber cultivation have been made, and whether .the Minister can give the Committee any assurance as to the adaptability of portions of Australia for the cultivation of this article, and I can inform him that in the Queensland Agricultural Journal, for September of this year, full information is given as to the localities and areas of land in Queensland that are suitable for the cultivation of rubber.
On what evidence are the statements made?

On the evidence of the expert in tropical agriculture who has charge of the State farm at Kamerunga, where rubber trees are being propagated, and where there are some trees which have arrived at maturity, and have been tapped for the rubber.
What I read showed that the trees had not been tapped.

I do not know what the honorable senator has read or what he wants, but it is evident that any stick is good enough to beat a dog with. During the consideration of the Bill, Senator Dobson has asked the Minister not to refer to the reports of the experts, because their statements were "all rubbish," but on this item the honorable senator says, " I wish the Minister would read the reports of the experts." The writer of the article from which I am quoting refers to the conditions requisite for the cultivation of Para rubber, and deals with the quality of soil, the necessary rainfall, and the suitable latitude. He writes—
speech.quote: In obtaining these conditions, the area more especially suitable for Para rubber in Queensland will be enclosed within an imaginary line drawn to include the Burdekin lands down by the junction of that river with the Suttor River' to the southward of North Queensland, following the course of this river northward into the valley of the Herbert, thence mounting the ranges (but to an elevation not exceeding r,50o to 2,ooo- feet, or where frost is met with) round to Oaklands on the Cairns-Atherton railway, and along the ranges northward to Princess Charlotte Bay. This must not be taken as a hard and fast line, however, for the area thus roughly indicated has perforce to include some small areas that have either insufficient rainfall, are too cold, or on which the soil is too poor and metalliferous for any agricultural operations. Generally speaking, the most suitable localities are in the valleys of out northern rivers, from the mouth of the Burdekin in the south to the Normanby in the north a distance of some 4,000 miles, including eighteen more or less important rivers, and roughly some 20,00 square miles of country.

speech.para: Does he give the rainfall?

Does the honorable senator believe that this man, who is an official of the Queensland Department of Agriculture, is such a fool that he does not know the rainfall of the districts which he describes in the reports which are submitted to Parliament? Does the honorable senator mean to insinuate that this State servant, paid and to give information to the public, is trying, by false representations, to induce people to enter into tropical industries?
He would not be the first public servant who had honestly made a mistake
But this officer does not give his own estimates of rainfall. He quotes the statistics supplied by other State Departments.
He further writes
speech.quote: Northward of this, and for that matter along the western coast of the North Queensland Peninsular, and into the Gulf of Carpentaria, localities with suitable rainfall, soil, temperature and rainfall may here and there be found, and southward of this most southernmost point mentioned isolated localities may also be found where, the climate being mild and the situation protected, Para rubber will grow.
speech.para: He refers to districts much further south where it is possible to find small patches of country complying with the description he gives; but points out that it is possible that plantations in those districts might be affected by frost. He goes into the whole question of soils, aspect, lay of land methods of propagations, planting, growth of the plants and cultivation, and also production and returns. Attached to the article there is a photograph of the rubber plantation established at Kamerunga. The plantation there is progressing, and he believes that it will give a considerable return, although so far only a few trees have sufficiently matured to warrent their being tapped a few times. I am given to understand that other people have gone into the industry, but it must not be forgotten that it requires a considerable amount of capital to establish a rubber plantation.The average settler, who must look for a return from his land with twelve or eighteen months, is unable to embark in this industry, from which a return cannot be expected for about six years. If, however, we pass this item, an inducement will be offered to people to enter upon the industry, because the will know that they will receive some assistance form the Government when they have produced the rubber.
Would the honourable senator recommend any man to put £4,000 or £5,000 into the rubber industry in Queensland?
I do not know that men usually take up these industries on the recommendation of others.
Exactly. "Try it on the dog"
If, in the opinion of Senator St Ledger, Queensland is the dog, I cannot compliment him upon his illustration.
At the same time, the honourable senator has not answered the question.

cannot answer the question. Members of the profession to which Senator St. Ledger belongs are accustomed to advise people that they have a case, though it is ten chances, to one that they have no case, and the honorable senator is presuming that I would advise some one to go into tan industry in which he might lose his money. It is not my business to give advice of that kind, but I believe that if the Government offer an inducement to people to embark upon this industry, those proposing to do so will make all the inquiries necessary, and if they are satisfied, will take up the work, exercising their own intelligence, and knowing that if they make a success of it they can look for some assistance in the for of a bounty. It is useless to ask a memeber of Parliament whether he would advise any to embark in an industry concerning which he may have no personal knowledgem and must depend on the information supplied by public officers appointed for the purpose. I do not think there is very much in thestatements we hear as to the enormous fortunes made in some industries. Evidence is given that in certain places, probably where there is any amount of cheap labour available, men have established industries from which they have derived large returns. In one of the articles on rubber, it is stated that in Borneo some people ave making as much as 93 per cent, profit on the money they have invested in the industry. They have an unlimited supply of cheap labour. Of course, I cannot say that any person who attempts to establish the rubber industry in North Queensland will earn 90 per cent, on his capital, but I do say that if people with sufficient capital, and • who 'can afford to remain out of their money for a time, will invest in the industry, they are likely to get a fair return; and that is all that any reasonable person asks. This is an industry that cannot be wiped out again the moment the bounty ceases. It takes a number of vears before rubber trees reach maturity, and if then the bounty were to cease the trees would go on bearing. There is certainly no danger of their being chopped down. It is a good thing for the Government to offer induce-' ments to people to try experiments in such directions. One of the principal reasons urged against the bounty is that rubber will be grown in Papua, and that we ought to leave the matter to that Territory. A number of articles have been published in the Queensland Agricultural Journal, showing that the demand for rubber is certainly increasing, and that new channels for its utilization are being opened. That seems to indicate that, having the soil, the temperature, and the rainfall, we can establish an industry in Australia that will, at all events, be sufficient to supply our own needs.
Which are considerable.

The figures quoted by Senator Findley show that we import over £300>00° worth of rubber and rubber goods per annum into the Commonwealth. The trade and Customs statistics also show that the Commonwealth manufactures and exports nearly J£I 1,000 worth of manufactured rubber goods. In the last vear fot which we ha.ve statistics we exported ,£1.900 worth to Papua, and over ,-£2,000 worth to the Argentine Republic. If the argument is to have force that we are not to give anv assistance to an industry in Australia because we ought to leave' the production of the article in question to Papua, what form of tropical agriculture shall we "be able to encourage ?
That rather misrepresents our argument, which was that it is a waste of money, with our dear labour, to try to compete against the cheap labour of Papua.

That was always the argument advanced in Queensland in favour of the employment of the kanakas. The Pacific Islander was first employed in that State to do shepherding. That was years before he was emploj'ed in the sugar industry. It is only because the Commonwealth decided to deal firmly with the black labour question that the kanaka has at length been expelled.
And the rest of Australia is growling about having to pay for it!
I do not think there has been any growling.
Honorable senators are always saying to the Queensland representatives, "What about your sugar bounty?"

And why? Because some Queensland representatives are -continually objecting to Government assistance being granted to any. industries in Australia, other than those which are conducted in their State. I am sorry to say that some of my fellow senators from Queensland are continually opposing proposals to grant assistance to other-industries except those which are confined to Queensland.
The sugar bounty was objected to before some of us came into tbe Senate.

few objected, but they were all on the side on which the honorable senator sits. The Royal Commission on British New Guinea, in their report, mention practically all the items affecting tropical agriculture included in this schedule, as being capable of production in Papua. They mention copra, rubber, sugar, coffee, tobacco and sisal hemp. Honorable senators opposite did not object to monev ibeing thrown away by the granting of a bounty for sisal hemp. Yet it can be grown easier in Papua than in the Commonwealth.
I thought the honorable senator said that we were opposing all the items?.
The honorable senator opposed a number, of bounties on products that can be grown in other parts of Australia than Queensland.

voted against one only, and that affected the whole of Australia. I intend to look at these matters from a broader stand-point than that of my own State only. I shall not vote for items simply because they concern Queensland. If I consider that any bounty .will assist in the establishment of industries in any part of Australia, I shall vote for it, even though my own State may not be affected.
Why did not the honorable senator vote for mohair?

That was the only item against which I voted, and it affected all Australia. But the honorable senator who interjects, and those associated with him, vote against every item in the Bill. 'He would have killed the measure at the second-reading stage if he had had his way. The Queensland experts, who are Government servants engaged in trying experiments for the benefit of the people of the State, point out that we have an area of country which, in respect of soil, rainfall, and other natural conditions, is suitable for the growth of rubber. The only valid objection that has so far been raised is on the ground of cost. The argument of those who make that objection is that, because there is black labour in Papua, which can be obtained in any quantities, we ought not to encourage- the growth of rubber in the Commonwealth by white labour.

(New South Wales) [12.14].—I hardly think that Senator Turley has put his case in a way that does justice to his own public spirit. If I understand his argument, it is that he claims some credit for having voted for every bounty proposed by this Bill which would benefit his own State, whilst he voted against the one item in the schedule which would make a bountv operative all over Australia. Having known the honorable senator for some time, I decline to believe that he would, on reconsideration, re-affirm that he voted against mohair because the benefit of the bounty would be general, and that his generosity is confined absolutely to the people of his own State. With, regard to rubber, I must say that I am extremely disappointed at the attitude taken up by those who believe in the principle of bounties. I should have thought that if there was one item as to which a bounty might be paid—though I do not believe in the principle of bounties at all—if there wa's one which could be defended—it was that for the encouragement of rubber-growing. But when I say that, I am bound to inquire whether rubber itself is entitled to a bounty. I look for information, and am bombarded from all sides of the Chamber with the evidence of experts. Senator Turley became in deadly earnest when laying great stress on the authority which we should attach to the declarations of public servalits. I have a recollection of some rather lively criticisms directed to public servants even by Senator Turley
In what connexion?
On the Public Service Act.
I did not have a word to say in connexion with it.

It was during the discussion which took place here not on the Act itself, but on the administration of the Act, some two or three years ago. The fact . is that public servants appear to be excellent authorities when they say something that suits our own case, but are to be contemptuously dismissed if their opinion does not happen to square with our own. We have first of all the experts' report, which Senator Symon referred to as our Bible. It gives us one statement. Next, Senator .Findley quotes, from the report of the Royal Commission on Papua, certain statements and figures, and then, out of his great consideration for the Committee, immediately proceeds to demolish them bv quoting from another expert, Mr. Staniforth Smith. Thus three sets of expert opinions are put before us, each contradicting the other. In what position are we to arrive at a common-sense or business-like conclusion? I mention this to show how ill-equipped the Committee are to deal with and determine this matter with the scant ancl contradictory information before us. • It is a matter of great regret that those who believe in the bounties system did not make an effort to prevail on the Government, who would have listened more readily to- suggestions from their side than from this. f> concentrate the money on a few items of great promise. In this case, the small amount offered will be utterly futile. If it is correct, as stated in the experts' report, that an acre of rubber trees, having reached the tapping age, will yield an income of jf.zoo, it follows that the total bounty which we are providing will call into existence no more than 100 acres of rubber trees.
The honorable senator voted against the increase which was proposed yesterday in another item.

Of course I did. I am not saying that I will support an increase in this case, but if I had the alternative of supporting a bounty large enough to call an industry into existence, or one which would be frittered away, I should be inclined to vote for the larger sum. Senator Turley looked surprised at my statement that the total area which the proposed bounty, if effective, will bring under cultivation, is 100 acres, but I base that calculation on this wonderful document, prepared by these public servants, with their lofty ideals and limitless attainments
Is there no possibility of increasing the amount before the fifteen years' period expires?

Of course there will be a possibility of increasing it, but a much more business-like course would have been followed if those who favour bounties had concentrated their efforts on a few articles, which, in my opinion, like this one, have more promise because more profit in them. We could have done more good by offering a substantial bounty, which might have had some effect. I am not able to conceive that any man, who refrains to-day from going into an industry which, he is told, will rrive him a gross return of £200 per acre, will go into it if we add on to that return a miserable bounty of 10 per cent. If those paper profits are there, and men refrain from taking.up the industry, to-day for the reasons stated by Senator Turley— the long period which must elapse before a return is obtained, and the fact that there is an element of risk, seeing that it is in the nature of an experiment—they are not likely to take it up for the sake of this paltry inducement.
I did not say that I believe in all those paper profits.

The honorable senator had a great deal to say in laudation of the authors of that document. As I think that possibly this is an industry which has some future in Australia^ and do not consider, in view of the world's demand for rubber, that Australia and Papua would come into competition, I look a little less unkindly upon this item than upon others, but the amount which it is proposed . to spend appears to be totally insufficient to be effective. The initial outlay required is too great, and the period that must elapse before any income can be obtained is too long. Any one who would go into the industry with a bounty would go into it without.

(Queensland) [12.23].—I desire to correct a statement made by Senator Millen. The honorable senator asserted that I had made a statement that I voted against the item " Mohair," because it applied to all Australia,-and voted for other items because they applied to Queensland only. That is not so
I knew that the honorable senator misstated himself.
I supported bounties for New Zealand flax, flax and hemp, and other articles, which I knew perfectly well would flourish in other parts of Australia, more than in Queensland.

(Queensland) [12.25].—I am surprised at the amount of opposition which has been shown to this item, more particularly by senators representing Queensland. • The reason they-give for their opposition is most extraordinary. They appear to think that because rubber can be grown profitably in Papua no encouragement should be given for its production in Australia. I was always under the impression that, while Papua is under our control, our first duty is to the Commonwealth, and our first business to develop the resources of the Continent. There is no doubt that the rubber industrv is extending with great rapidity. I believe "that the demand for rubber will soon be verv much greater than it is now. The next question to consider is whether rubber can be "grown in Australia. There is r.o doubt that we can grow rubber.
And lose money on it.

We have these prophets of evil always with us. No matter .how often you bowl them out, they come up smiling again and again. The earlv squatters, when thev were deprived of convict labour, said that the industry would go to rack and ruin.
Very large sums have been lost in rubber cultivation in •Queensland.

Large sums have been lost in squatting, mining, and sugar growing, and some people even lose money by going into Parliament. I do not profess to be an expert on rubber. I have no extreme confidence in experts, but we must take their advice upon occasions and act upon it. An article upon rubber planting appeared in April, 1900, in the Queensland Agricultural Journal, to the following effect—
speech.quote: Certain portions of Queensland appear to possess a soil, climate, and timber growth identical, except in the kinds of timber, with the conditions found on the Atlantic or Gulf sides of Mexico. This zone includes portions of the States of Vera Cruz, Oaxaca, Chiapas, and Tabasco. Here the temperature ranges in summer from 73 deg. to q6 deg. F., and in winter from 55 deg. to 86 deg. The rainfall varies from 95 to 130 inches per annum. It is under these conditions'that the variety of rubber, Cas-tilloa clastica flourishes best. If we consider the climatic conditions of the districts around Cairns, Geraldton, and Cardwell we shall find that in rainfall, temperature, soil, and elevation they compare most favorably with the conditions which obtain on the Atlantic side of Mexico. At Geraldton the mean annual rainfall is 148.80 inches; the rainfall during 1898 reached 139.94 inches, the number of wet days being 146. At Cairns the mean annual rainfall is 98.34, and at Cardwell 87.54, with 131 and 106 rainy days respectively. The summer heat on the Johnstone River varies from 85 to 95 degrees Fahr. at midday in the shade; the winter temperature ranges from 70 to 80 degrees Fahr. At 10 p.m. the summer range is from 70 to So' degrees Fahr., and the winter temperature at the same hour averages from 40 to 60 degrees Fahr. The jungle consist of a dense mass of lawyer canes, bamboos, bananas, climbing raspberries, vines, with an occasional clump of trees. The soil is of the very richest description, having a depth of from 10 to 20 feet of the same character as that on the surface. Vast stretches of this fertile land are still unalienated. Standing on-the summit of a hill, one looks over a vast expanse of level country stretching away in all directions and covered with the primeval scrub. In the upper reaches of the south branch of the river, where a waterway has been cut through the volcanic soil by the water, a depth of even 100 feet of soil identical with that on the surface is visible.

speech.para: Is it still Crown land ?
I suppose that a very considerable area of if is still Crown land. Of course, the area is not so large as it was when the article was written.
speech.quote: Here, then, we have the ideal _ country for the growth of the rubber tree. It will be observed that the clearing of these scrubs is not nearly such a formidable undertaking as the work in the southern scrubs, where the timber is of great size and growing closely together. It would then appear that the best way in which to plant the rubber trees would be to 'clear lanes through the scrub 'in which the planting could be carried out. There has, however, been considerable controversy as to the advisability of planting in the shade or in the sun. As to soils, we have already pointed out that the rich scrub soils are best suited to the rubber tree; but good trees can be met with growing in gravelly clays, although none are found in ill-drained clay soils or swamps. In the case .of trees growing in the open, 250 to 300 trees per acre meet Mr. Harvey's idea for permanent growth, though in the beginning the tre.es are grown close, about 4 to 6 feet apart, to' shade the ground and keep the weeds down. Then in the second, third, and fourth vears thinning out is done, and a little rubber obtained' from trees 5 to 10 feet high, which may be destroved to allow room for the development of the permanent trees.
speech.para: I think that what I have read from the article proves clearly that in Queensland we have the soil and the climate. The industry is a rapidly expanding one. The demand is likely to be very much greater twenty, or even fifty, years hence than it is to-day, so that there need be no fear of plantations being established and no demand being ultimately found for the commodity. With regard to the time which it takes before a plantation gives a return, the article says—
speech.quote: Some writers say that five years is sufficient time to wait before commencing to tap, whilst others recommend seven or eight. No doubt excessive draining of sap before the trees attain size and strength would be injurious, but, as there appears to be every probability of a long era of high prices, careful calculations show that a good profit can be made on a plantation which is made to begin yielding in five years, provided the average yield for the next five years is 1 lb. per tree,'even if the trees should be exhausted by that time. With 300 trees to the acre, yielding 1 Ib. each at 40 cents (gold) per lb. as the local selling value, the return for five crop years would be $600 per acre, with a necessary investment not above $80. Much higher figures, for both yield and prices, are calculated on by most planters, but so far as Mr. Harvey is concerned, if this estimate were cut in half by actual results, the reward for time and money spent would probably exceed in profit any other known agricultural enterprise. Now, there are many planters in the North who cultivate the richest of Australian land on the banks of the rivers before mentioned. With an expenditure of a fraction of their time they might sow a few hundred seed -of the Castilloa elastica both in the open and in the partly cleared scrub. If the trial prove successful, they would have provided a splendid asset for themselves and their posterity. If it failed, they would still have done good service by showing that rubber cultivation in North Queensland could not be carried out with any hope of success.
speech.para: It must be evident to any one who cares to give the smallest attention to the matter that in portions of Australia we have country which is admirably suited for the. production of rubber. Some honorable senators have asked the question, "If it is such a profitable industry why have men not gone into it without the stimulus of a bounty?" Any one who has paid the slightest attention to the development of Australian industry need have no difficulty in answering that question. He ought to know quite well that the Australian farmer is the most conservative individual, that it is the most difficult task in the world to jog or jostle him out of a particular rut, that he must be either driven out by absolute poverty or tempted out by the prospect of a rich reward. That is m) experience of the average Australian farmer.
hese conservative men generally support the honorable senator's side in politics.

I do not trouble very much' who supports me so long as I get here. I suppose that the vote of a conservative counts one just as the vote of a most rabid radical would do. In any case, we are making an attempt to encourage the establishment of new industries.- Let us not be dismayed by the prospect of failure. If that prospect had influenced the men who lived in Australia 50 or 100 years ago, we should not be discussing these matters in this palatial building. I, with others, think that the Government might very well have devoted a much larger sum to the encouragement of the rubber industry than it has done. But I am not going to reject this-proposal simply because.it is a very small one. If the industry gives the prospect of being promoted by the very slight encouragement which the Government is now proposing to offer additional encouragement can be given at a later period. I ask honorable senators to throw aside their fears and to strike out boldly for a large and generous policy of development. Australian .progress cannot be promoted by men of little faith, shivering in their shoes and afraid to take the slightest step forward in case they should meet witb defeat. That is not the kind of spirit that ought to animate the people who are living in Australia to-day.
They belong to the " Do-Nothing, Stand-Still Party."
They appear to belong to the party who are all right themselves and who, for that reason, appear to think that nothing should be done to benefit anybody else.
We have a regard for the people of Papua.

I probably have as much regard for those people as has anybody else. There are half-a-million natives in Papua, and they are very much better off than are a large number of the women and men who live on the mainland. My fear is that if the Commonwealth tinkers too much with Papua then, instead of improving the conditions of its people, it may do the very opposite.
They have always plenty of food to eat.

Yes, with very little work to do. I do -not believe that any one of us is particularly anxious to work if he can get what he wants without working. I appeal once more to honorable senators to support this little vote for rubber, and so encourage what may in the future prove to be a very large and important industry in .Australia.
(Western Australia) [12.45].—I would like to support this item.
Let the honorable-senator give his inclinations full play.

I would support fhe item if I thought that there was a shred of a chance of the effort to establish the rubber industry succeeding in this country. We have only to look abroad to see what is happening in other parts of the world in-connexion with the production of rubber to know that it is utterly hopeless to expect that we shall be able to establish tho industry successfully in Australia.
Why?

The authority quoted by the Minister mentions the large investment of capital in recent years in this industry in countries where there is cheap labour as well as cheap land, and it is impossible for us with our high standards-to compete with the production of those-countries. I went to some trouble to communicate with the gentleman who contributed the article from which the Minister has quoted, but I found that he was not very willing to give any further information with respect to the industry than that which has appeared in the daily press. It is, however, clear from what he has stated' in his article that very great attention has in recent years been directed to the production of rubber in other countries. He has stated that up to 1904 the world was entirely dependent for. its supply on the rubber growing wild in South America, Central Africa, and other tropical countries, but from that date onwards the attention given to the production of this article has been such that no less than 137 companies have been formed in London to engage in the industry in Ceylon, Malay, Mexico, Central "Africa, and Central Asia, with the result that in addition to the supplies of " wild " rubber there are now no less than 17,000,000 plantation trees which will in a very few years give an increased supply amounting to some 15,000 tons, or an increase of over 25 per cent, on the world's present production.
If we give a bounty some of the companies might come this way.

It is a wonder and a pity that they have not come this way, but the fact that they have not done so is a proof that in their opinion the countries to which they have gone present a far more favorable theatre for their operations. I said that I would support the item if I thought there were a chance of the successful establishment of .the industry in Australia, but I believe that rubber must be placed with tea amongst the articles which cannot be profitably grown in Australia. .Tea can be produced in Australia, but at a price which I should be unwilling to pay for it. In speaking on the second reading of the Bill I mentioned the fact that ITiad myself drunk excellent tea produced in Fiji under climatic conditions precisely similar to those prevailing in North Queensland. I brought packages of that tea to Sydney sixteen, years1 ago. Why do we not encourage the growth of tea in Australia ? Is it not because we know that it is produced in India and China at a cost with which we could not compete, and that it could be produced here only at a cost which is absolutely prohibitory.
Would not that apply to everything that is produced in India and China ?
I am, in common with Senator Findley, a- protectionist, but I would hazard the opinion that the honorable senator would not go so far as to offer a bounty for the production of tea in Australia.
I would, if it can be grown in Australia.

There is no doubt that it can be grown in Australia, or that rubber can be grown in Australia, but it would be at a price which would not justif y us in granting a bounty. The writer of the article referred to by the Minister deals with the various uses to which rubber is-being applied. He speaks of its use for a pavement at St. Pancras, in London, but he does not say whether as a! result of their experience of its use there the London County Council favour its general adoption for the purpose.
Because the supply is so scarce that it would be too dear.

I can imagine no contingency so detrimental to the success of the industrv in Australia as a reduction in the price of* the article. If the price of rubber comes down substantially the outlook for its production in Australia, under the standards which I hope we shall continue to maintain here, would become hopeless. In speaking on the second-reading of the Bill, and referring to the primary object for which the States experts were called together in conference—the preparation of a list of agricultural products to assist the production of which it would be wise to offer bounties—I said that in omitting to recommend that assistance should be given for the discovery and working of phosphatic deposits in Australia, the experts had utterly failed in their "duty. It is the application of improved machinery and of fertilizers to the agricultural industry which enables us to hold our own in Australia against the productions of even cheap labour countries. Whilst every effort is made to secure improvements in agricultural machinery, no substantial effort is made to bring a cheap fertilizer within the reach of the struggling settler. The need for a cheap fertilizer has been lost sight of by the experts' who have been called upon for their advice, and on that account I repeat that they have failed in their duty.
Fertilizers are being manufactured with perfect success and in great quantities already in Australia.
Last year Australia imported about 160,000 tons of fertilizers.
The honorable senator should not mention the fact, or the Government will clap a duty upon fertilizers.

The neglect of the several Australian Governments to devise a scheme for the discovery and working of phosphafic deposits imposes a sufficient duty on fertilizers at the present time. It is my intention to move that the item " Rubber " be omitted with a view to provide a bounty, at the same rate and covering the same period, for the discovery and working of phosphatic deposits in Australia.
Can we change an item in that way ?
I propose to ask the Committee to do so.

I ask the honorable senator not to discuss the proposal he has foreshadowed, as the first question to be submitted to the Committee, should he move his suggested amendment^ would be the omission of certain words from the schedule.
Then I move--
speech.quote: That the words "Rubber ... 15 years. . . 10 per cent, on market value" be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words "Phosphatic Deposits. ... 10 years ... 15 per cent, on market value.

speech.para: I rise to a point of order. I submit that the honorable senator's amendment cannot be accepted. It has been ruled that we can strike put certain items in the schedule, and subsequently transfer to other items the amounts set against those we have strupk out, but I contend that we have no power to strike out an item in the scheduleNfor the purpose of substituting a new item. If the amendment were in order it would be possible to alter every item in the schedule and so frame an absolutely new Bill.
We might provide for a bounty on canned pineapples before we have done.
I submit that the amendment is not relevant to the Bill, and I hope the Chairman will rule that it cannot be submitted.

The only matter that can be debated at this stage is the proposed omission of the words " Rubber . . . 15 years ... 10 per cent, on market value." It is perfectly competent for any honorable senator to move the amendment. No point of order can be raised on Senator 'Lynch's proposal to provide a bounty for the discovery and working of phosphatic deposits until the question for the insertion of the words to which he has referred is before the Committee. I cannot be called upon at this stage to give, a ruling upon an amendment that is not before the Committee.

On the amendment that. the words now appearing in the schedule be left out, will it be competent for any honorable senator to discuss the proposal which Senaitor Lynch has submitted? If so, the discussion on the schedule mav be continued into next week.
Is the honorable senator raising another point of order?
I am asking for information ?
I cannot- give rulings on hypothetical cases.

When we were dealing with cotton, a favourite and justifiable argument used was that, by the application of improved machinery, Australia would be able to hold her own against the cheap labour of cotton-producing countries. But in the case of rubber the initial cost of clearing the land in our tropical areas would be very great.
It does not cost much to clear land there.
It costs more to clear land in the tropical parts of Australia than anywhere else.
How much ?

lt costs anything up to £30 per acre. We are told in the experts' report that rubber is indigenous to the Northern Territory, and also grows very well in Queensland, and that Where the rubber tree abounds the country is thickly timbered. So that, if we encourage men to embark in such a foolish enterprise they will necessarily have to spend a considerable amount of money in clearing the ground preparatory to planting the rubber trees; and when they have incurred this initial expenditure they will have to compete against the products of cheap labour countries. It seems hopeless for us in Australia to expect to compete successfully in rubber growing. But what is the alternative? We have the Territory of Papua alongside Australia. Although we have not the direct interest in Papua that we have in our • own country, nevertheless it cannot be denied that we are concerned with the development of that country. One. of its chief industries is likely to be rubber production. We must rely upon Papua as a source of supply in this respect. We have an interest in the development of Papua which we cannot afford to neglect. It seems illogical for us to enter into competition with a Papuan industry which will be able to produce all the rubber we require for our own wants. The next point is— can we successfully produce rubber for sale in the markets of the world? I hold that we cannot, in view of the fact that since 1904 various wealthy companies have embarked capital in plantations sufficient to' produce more rubber than can be easily consumed. The bounty will lead to no good, and as soon as profits diminish through its cessation the industry must fail. It is hopeless for us to expect that with our white labour we can compete against black labour countries.
Have we not done it in the matter of sugar production ?

Sugar and rubber are not in the same category. I have already intimated my intention of voting against the item, with a view of proposing a bounty for the encouragement of the discovery of deposits of phosphates. If we can afford any assistance in that direction we shall greatly aid in the promotion of agriculture. In the Agricultural Journal of Victoria it is pointed out what limitless possibilities of agricultural development are afforded by the use of fertilizers. I shall deal with this subject further at an appropriate time. Meanwhile I shall vote against the item.

(South Australia) [2.10] 1 am sorry that Senator Lynch, in his excellent desire to encourage the production of phosphates, the value of which cannot be over-estimated, has selected rubber as the item to be sacrificed to carry out his idea.
