The production of rubber offers a most promising opportunity for the application of a bounty, and those who desire to develop the Northern Territory should be particularly anxious to vote for it. It is a product the demand for which is increasing enormously. No other product that can be mentioned is in such demand. That demand is likely to increase within the next few j'ears. It is true that there are difficulties about producing rubber in Australia. But if there were no difficulties to contend with there would be no necessity for a bountv.
Why not grant bounties to encourage the finding of radium in pitch blend?

I do not say that it would not be desirable at a later period to grant bounties for the production of other commodities. But because an honorable senator may think that a bounty should be given for the production of something else, that is no reason why we should vote against the items included, in the schedule. If we were to act upon the idea that because certain industries are flourishing in other parts of the world there is no hope for them in Australia, we should do nothing to develop the country. Sufficient evidence has been adduced to show that there is reason for encouraging the production of rubber. At all events, we should endeavour to give it a start. The bounty proposed is not a large one-only 10 per cent.- for fifteen years. At the end of that time the plantations will be bearing, and our producers will probably be able to contend against competition. I should be very happy indeed to support Senator Lynch in a proposal to grant a bounty for the discovery of deposits of phosphates; but why do that in substitution for the item under discussion? Why not grant an additional bounty for that purpose ? We cannot over-estimate the importance of phosphates to the farming community. Their use has simply revolu-tipnized production in my own State. They have brought into profitable cultivation lands which had become wheat sick, and were producing, literally nothing. They have enabled farmers to rise from poverty to a condition of prosperity. The phosphate industry is one which we should all desire to foster. But, while I am willing to assist Senator Lynch, yet that is no reason why I should vote against a bountv for rubber.

(Western Australia) [2.15].—I am quite in accord with Senator O'Loghlin's desire to assist Senator Lynch, if possible, in his very laudable intention, but I do not agree with his attitude towards this item. Clear and suffi-cent arguments have been adduced to show that the item should stand. The item coffee would have been much more readily accepted by me as a means by which Senator Lynch could introduce his amendment. It has been fully shown that the production of rubber is an industry with great prospects, notwithstanding the morbid ideas of some Queensland senators about the extraordinary march of the chemists. They have probably fallen into the same error as the experts. They have not looked sufficiently long at the fact .that the chemists have been employed in the search for a substitute for rubber for a. large number of years, and that their endeavours so far have absolutely failed.
That is exactly what was said with regard to indigo

The honorable senator is very much afraid of the chemists, but when we were discussing a previous item, where it was shown that great possibilities existed of the skill of the engineer and mechanic being applied to economizing the processes of production, the honorable senator was so sceptical that he could not believe that the engineer or mechanic could go a foot beyond what had already been done. The honorable senator is, therefore, not consistent. I recognise as fully as any other honorable senator our obligations to Papua, and our duty to assist the development of industries natural to that country, but at the same time there are areas within the continent itself which have great possibilities.
Our responsibilities are to those whom we represent here

Those are our responsibilities, first and foremost, and then in a secondary manner, we are responsible to those whom we profess to protect. The use of rubber is becoming so extensive that no man can, at this moment, forecast any limitations to it. I am satisfied that the item should be retained in the schedule

(Queensland) [2.20].—Those who are supporting this measure will find, if they turn to the pages of Hansard, that the greater portion pf the time given to its consideration has been occupied in defending it, aind certainly not in any attack upon it. Senator Henderson should remember that with the enormous increase in the uses of rubber there has been nearly a parallel increase in its production. The world's output of crude rubber is now valued at £27,381,000, but only ,£1,500,000, or, roughly speaking, one twenty-sixth of that amount, is the product of the cultivated rubber. All the rest is the product of the " wild " rubber. I mentioned yesterday that in Mexico and in Arizona a. new species of rubber plant has been discovered, and will add considerably to the world's output.
That is questioned in one of the Agricultural Journals.

The article I quoted gives the names of the factories treating the plant, and the exact cost of harvesting. The information is clear and •definite, and unless it can' be contradicted by something more convincing than a mere statement that experts somewhere or other do not agree with it, I shall have to accept it as correct. Some honorable senators are inclined to vote for the item on the ground that otherwise they will be expressing the opinion that rubber cannot be grown in the northern parts of Australia. A representative of Western Australia, in another place, on my askinr* him. what was the largest rainfall in Western Australia, told me that it was 58 inches per annum. That is nothing like sufficient to grow rubber. At Palmerston, in. the Northern Territory, there is a rainfall of 70 inches, but that is during four months in the year only. All experts agree that a continuously hot, moist climate is necessary to grow Para and Ceara rubbers—the two cultivated varieties. It is of no use to blink the fact that, we do not possess that climate in the Northern Territory, or in Northern Queensland, except along' the north-eastern seaboard. When I was in the Northern Territory, Judge Herbert told me that the countrv around Palmerston was exactly similar to that around Port Moresby, and on the western and south-western coast ot Papua. But for a parallel to a really tropical climate such as that on the northeastern coast of Queensland, we must no to the eastern coast of Papua. With all due respect to the other experts who have spoken on the subject, including honoiable senators, my opinion is that rubber can not be satisfactorily cultivated in Australia, except along the north-eastern coast of Queensland. The reports that have been submitted to us almost invariably refer to those districts in Queensland where, at the present time, sugar, and hemp to some extent, are being cultivated, and where they are beginning to cultivate cotton and coffee.
What rainfall is necessary for the successful cultivation of the rubber plant?

From 90 to 120 inches. It is stated that at one place along the Queensland coast the rainfall is as high as 200 inches. That undoubtedly refers to Geraldton, where in one year there was a fall of 240 inches. In fact, it was measured in yards. I admit that that is a very suitable place for rubber cultivation, but we have another industry there now. The Commonwealth has, and is getting under its control, new Territories, and the Australian people are being taxed to develop them. Some industries must be left to those places. If we seek to establish those industries in our midst in opposition to them, their natural tendency will be to undertake other industries which are now being successfully carried on in Queensland, and which can be undertaken with equal success in certain portions of the Northern Territory. I do not honestly believe that rubber-growing can obtain any great dimensions in Queensland or the Northern Territory, particularly in consequence of the competition that must inevitably result from the efforts being made to establish the industry in' Papua. The Royal Commission recently appointed to inquire into affairs in Papua reported most encouragingly on the prospects of rubber cultivation there. But they put down the .cost of felling, clearing and holing at £T an acre. On the other hand ai report, which I take it .is furnished by Mr. Newport, who is ah excellent authority on coffee, states the cost of the same work in Queensland at from £2 to £4 an acre, so doubling or quadrupling the expense at the very outset. The Commission put down the' cost of labour in Papua at £3 a head a year, to which., of course, would have to be added about 30s. a year for recruiting.
Is the £3 for wages ?

Yes, but no doubt the men would have to be found in food, clothes and tobacco. It will be seen from that report that the cost of labour will be very much lower in Papua than in Queensland. I feel sure that the attractions which are being offered by the Papua Administration in the form of cheap land, and the introduction of a large number of seeds and plants from other countries, will lead to the attention of people being diverted to Papua instead of to Queensland. I suppose it will be said once more that if this money is not spent no harm will be done. I hope that the time is not far distant when we shall be able to say that some of the tropical industries which we are now encouraging have attained such dimensions that it is advisable, in the interests of the country generally, that they should be encouraged further. We shall then be faced with the fact that a large sum of public money has been earmarked for certain industries which are not being started, and which therefore are not likely to be carried on. For that reason, I strongly urge that the Committee will not be doing any harm to Australia by striking out this item. If it is deleted, it will be within the.power of the Parliament later on to give some assistance to industries which are likely to become large and important to the whole of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: (Western Australia) [2.35].—I am entirely opposed to this item. I do not propose to quote rusty evidence for the purpose of substantiating my position. I consider that there is very little need to quote further evidence than that which is contained in the report of the Conference of Experts. Those gentlemen, I presume, were appointed for the express purpose, of inquiring into the prospects of certain industries, and furnishing such information as they thought absolutely necessary for the guidance of this Parliament. That, in my opinion, was a very wise course for the Government 'to adopt. The experts show very clearly that there is no- reason why we should make the slightest attempt to coddle the coffee industry. Every time I read their report on the subject of coffee-growing, I wonder how they managed to arrive at its first paragraph, particularly after one has read and considered the following paragraphs.
Long before I got to the report on coffee-growing I ceased to be surprised at anything.

Probably I had been surprised at one or two statements, but undoubtedly the report on the coffee industry was the greatest surprise of all. The first paragraph reads— While a very general feeling prevailed that coffee planting was not likely—at any rate in the near future—to become an important Australian industry, Conference is of opinion that steps should be taken to encourage it. Are there any words which could be selected- to express greater condemnation of this item than the words of thait paragraph ? The experts say in effect, " You may endeavour to build up the coffee industry by means of a bounty, but wfe tell you very clearly that it is utterly impossible that within the near future it can be of any value to Australia, Notwithstanding our condemnation, we blindfold ourselves and advise you to make an endeavour to encourage the industry." Evidence, of that character ought . to point out to us what is our common duty with regard to the item.
Did not the experts say nearly the same thing about the rubber industry ?

In that case the experts did not write quite so strongly. They did not clearly show that an attempt to establish the rubber industry would fail, but they clearly show that it will be futile to endeavour to encourage the coffee industry. I intend to quote the whole • of their evidence on this subject in order that it may appear in Hansard, and the public may have an opportunity of learning what the experts did suggest to the Senate in respect of this item. In the second paragraph of their report the experts say—
speech.quote: Can be produced over large areas of the tropical and sub-tropical portions of the Continent. The returns, however, from the plantations, are not at all alluring, while the consumption of coffee by the people of the Commonwealth is on a very slender scale. The experience of the chief coffee producing countries of the world, and these are countries where an abundant supply of cheap labour is obtainable—does not afford much hope for the extensive and successful exploitation of the industry under Australian conditions.
speech.para: They go on to say—
speech.quote: They go on to say— Tn Brazil, for instance, sufficient coffee is produced to meet the requirements v of the whole world, the figures being as under:— Year 1901-2, world's consumption—15,500,000 sacks; Year 1901-2, Brazilian production—15,496,000 sacks.
speech.para: It will be seen that this leaves a very small portion indeed to be supplied by other countries, even including the Malay States. There is another reason why we should strike out this item. We have endeavoured to assist this industry since 1902. We have been told that in some parts of Queensland playful efforts have been, and are still being, made to produce coffee. I am justified in referring to these efforts as "playful" from the statements made by Senators Chataway and St. Ledger, who informed us that coffee was being produced in Queensland on little patches of land by men who were engaged in other industries, and who grew coffee as a sort of recreation.
Who told the honorable senator that?
That must have been the impression left upon the mind of every honorable senator by the honorable senator.
It is an inference only.

The honorable senator's inferences are often of more value than his straight-out statements. We have evidence that for a number of years people have been playing at the production of coffee in Queensland, to fill in their spare time, and afford them relief from other occupations. We have had sufficient evidence to prove that by the offer of a bounty we cannot make the production of coffee a success when we have been unable to clo so by the imposition of a duty. Since 1902 we have imposed a duty of 3d. per lb. on raw coffee. That is equivalent to at least 33 per cent, on the value of the article. That duty has been recently increased by half as much again. If those who had been growing coffee for a number of years in Queensland cannot extend their operations with the assistance provided by the duty, what hope »;an we have that we shall be able to coddle the industry with a bounty ? It is admitted that coffee must be grown in little patches here and there, and that there is no possibility of its production being undertaken on a large scale. We have seen that Brazil grows abundant coffee to supply the whole of the world's consumption of the article. There are coffee plantations in other countries, in which the industry is carried on under conditions similar to those prevailing on the Brazilian plantations. In the circumstances, we have to face the fact that to keep the industry going in Australia it will be necessary, after the bounty has ceased to operate, to increase the duty on coffee by 100 per cent. I am not at present arguing against the increase of the duty on coffee, but I ask whether, in the face of the evidence before us, the industry is one which justifies the payment of a bounty. Although Brazil can produce coffee sufficient for the world's consumption, the statement is made that the Brazilian.planters are pulling up many of their coffee plants, and a law has been passed in that country preventing the expansion of the industry for a limited time. All this goes to prove that it is impossible to develop the industry in Australia under the high protection that is at present- enjoyed, that it will be a useless waste of money to grant the proposed bounty, and that, if it is granted, when it ceases to operate we must look to other resources to coddle the industry for all time. The experts further report—
speech.quote: It is also an ominous fact that according to ' the Trofen-pjlanzer—a recognised authority on all tropical matters—the p.lanters of Brazil have not only destroyed large quantities of coffee berry because of the low prices prevailing, but .have' also pulled up ths bushes growing on large areas of coffee plantation,' and are using the land for other purposes. The records available of Australian experience in coffee growing are bv no means encouraging. In the year' 1903 there were 318 acres under coffee in'Qucensland, the total yield being 83.632 lbs. Valuing this at 9d. .per lb.—which is allowed to be a fair average price—the return would not be more than £\o per acre. Considering the labor involved in clearing and preparing the land, in picking and cleaning for market, and bearing in mind the fact that the plantation does not become productive until it is four years old, this return appears totally inadequate. With all these disadvantages, the fact remains that coffee of a good type can be produced over large portions of Northern Australia, and accordingly a bonus of id. per lb. for eight years is recommended.
speech.para: Because there is land in the Commonwealth on which coffee can be grown, the experts recommend that a bounty of id. per lb. for eight years should be granted to encourage the industry. There is one other thing which I wish to say. I am well aware that there are some people who think that coffee-growing can be carried on very cheaply. I have heard it stated that even school children can carry out the work of picking the 'berries, and can do it very successfully.
The report of the experts suggests that.
So it does, and the moment I come face to face with an industry which encourages the exploitation of school children, I set myself dead against it.
What about the cotton industry?
I am just as strongly against the exploitation of children in the cotton industry. On the evidence supplied' in the report of the Conference of Experts I shall oppose the item.

(Queensland) [3.0].—I speak with some diffidence with, regard to this item. Unlike some of the Solons opposite, I do not pose as an agricultural authority. The figures which I shall give are not my own, and I shall leave honorable senators to draw their own inferences from them. The Committee has decided to grant bounties • amounting to ,£30,000 for the encouragement of rubber growing, although not one ounce of rubber has yet been produced in Australia.
Is the honorable senator in order in referring to an item that has been passed by the Committee?
I understand the honorable senator to be discussing the item " Coffee.". He has meiely mentioned rubber incidentlv.

I merely stated the fact that we have already agreed to a bounty on a product, not one ounce of which has yet been produced in Australia. Coffee, however, stands upon an entirely different footing. It is an article which we have a reasonable hope of producing successfully.
Is the honorable senator explaining why he voted against rubber ?

I am not troubling myself about consistency or inconsistency. Some honorable senators opposite have taken upon themselves the role of sharpshooter with regard to me. Senator Turley is one of them. But, hereafter, all one has to do to him is to use the word " mohair " when he gets up. I wish to give some figures with regard to coffee cultivation in Queensland. I take them from the statistics of tliat State, published by authority, and dated 1905. That information will relieve Senator Turley's soul, and he will not be put to the awful necessity of snowing that I am inconsistent in quoting them. In 1896, the growth of coffee seems to have been commenced in Queensland. In that year, there were 26 acres under coffee, producing 9,707 lbs.; in 1897, there were 180 acres, which produced 88,614 lbs; in 1898, 199 acres, producing 56,552 lbs.; in 1899, 223 acres, .producing 104,981 lbs.; in 1900, 283 acres, producing 102,134 lbs.; in 1901, 370 acres, producing 130,293 lbs.; in 1902, 314 acres, producing 113,301 lbs.; in 1903, 318 acres, producing 83,632 lbs.; in 1904, 292 acres, producing 132,554 lbs.; in *9°5> 335 acres, producing 82,230 lbs. So that there was a steady increase in the growth of coffee from 1896 to 1901. In 1901, the duty on coffee was reduced by the Commonwealth Parliament. Before Federation, it was 4d. per lb.; in 1901,. it became 3d. Between .1901 and 1902 there was a drop in production from 370 to 314 acres, and by 1904 there had been a further decrease to 292 acres.
That was caused by the land being devoted to sugar culture.

I am simply quoting facts. I am well aware that there are Solons and Solomons opposite who are capable of interpreting them, and who, when I venture to draw my own inferences from facts, accuse me of being almost a scoundrel. But I know thaf they speak only in a Pickwickian sense
The honorable senator does not know them!

The honorable senator should not try to drag a red herring across the scent. To do so is only worthy of a brilliant ornament of the stinking-fish party. The figures that I have quoted show that there was for some years a steady growth in coffee production in Queensland. Whether that was due to the State Tariff is a question that does not now concern me. At all events, it is clear that coffee growing can be carried on in Australia. If honorable senators opposite think that the industry can be conducted with a reasonable chance of success, they ought to be inclined to give it a start. Senator Henderson has stated that, during the course of a speech I made some time ago, I said that the growing of cotton, coffee, and kindred products could be taken up as a kind of recreation to supplement other industries. I am not aware that I made such a. statement. I did say, however, that young persons who have left school can engage in these industries without any undue strain upon them. I venture to say, too, that assuming that an industry was remunerative, I would rather see any one belonging to me engaged in an outdoor occupation of this kind than have them sweated in one of the Melbourne factories. Some time ago, I visited a flourishing coffee plantation near Cairns. It is owned by a Mr. Street. I spent a day with him in company with some professional friends from Brisbane. He had established his industrv at the top of the range, aided by his family. His boys and girls were a credit, not only to him, but to Australia. The family had every kind of reasonable comfort, and there was every evidence of intelligence and refinement in their home. This man's son, a fine, strapping young fellow, was engaged in the industry, and showed no signs of physical deterioration through the work. As this policy is bound to affect the labour conditions of Australia, it is our duty to discriminate in favour of those industries which do not enervate our young people as against those which must degrade them. This gentleman pointed out the difficulties that he had to contend with.. He said, " I do not care a straw about your black or yellow labour. I haye shown that I can carry on the industry, but what I do want is some protection. Through a decrease in the duty on coffee I am afraid that I cannot compete, but if the Commonwealth Parliament had left the duty at the same rate as under the old Queensland Tariff I would have been able to make a success of it." The duty under the Queensland Tariff was, I believe, 4d., but under the Commonwealth Tariff it was reduced by id. per lb. He said that owing to the reduction in the duty he doubted whether his son would remain with him, and whether he could carry on the plantation, but he • added that he would try. I do not know the ultimate history of that experiment in coffee-growing, but I believe he is there still. What is the position of honorable senators who supported bounties for jute and rubber—and not a pound of rubber will be produced in Australia—and yet oppose a bounty for coffee? I have shown from the figures that, although the increase in the coffee industry has been small, it has still been at reasonably sound and hopeful one. If I adopted the ungenerous and uncharitable insinuations that have been hurled at us from the other side of the chamber, what taunts might I not have hurled against those who are opposing this item? I know that in supporting it so strongly I am leaving myself open to the charge of inconsistency. But I want to banish that kind of childish argument from the •Chamber. I assume that we are all trying to do our best for the industries of Australia, and, as the Government are determined to support some industries by bounties, to advance the best arguments we can find in support of the most deserving tmes. I am entitled in these circumstances to ask that the best intelligence of the Committee should be devoted, without any party prejudice or feeling, to the interests of those industries which can be established in Australia.
How long did the duty on coffee obtain in Queensland before the Federal Tariff was introduced?

I am not in a position to give exact information, but I think that a fairly strong protective Tariff was imposed in Queensland about 1887. It was regarded in Australia as one of the best instances of a scientific Tariff, and one of the industries which got the benefit of protection, if it was a benefit, was coffee. The figures show that the industry in 1896 showed a very fair promise. The evidence I have given proves conclusively that there are reasonable hopes for the industry in Australia. Coffee grows in a portion of Northern Queensland which has a climate remarkably suited for white men—a" tableland climate entirely different from that along the coast. I am entitled to discriminate between items like rubber and jute, and others like cotton and coffee, which can be grown in places in Queensland eminently suitable for our own white people, and the cultivation o'f which has been successfully undertaken there by white men. Of course, when one begins to discriminate he lays himself open to the accusation of not discriminating properly.
Can the honorable senator say .whether the expansion of the production of coffee in Queensland took place under a smaller or. greater import duty than the duty in the present Commonwealth Tariff?

I cannot say. I can quite understand Senator Lynch opposing the item on some of the grounds whicli he has already advanced, but I cannot see how Senator Henderson, from what he has said, can oppose the encouragement of the coffee industry in Queensland. The figures certainly look very hopeful compared with those relating to other items to which we have already agreed to give bounties. I think I am entitled to adopt every one of the arguments that have been used in this Committee in favour of jute, rubber, and even mohair, in support of a bounty on coffee, in spite of any imputation of inconsistency.
How is the honorable senator going to vote? I cannot make him out.
If the honorable senator does not understand me, I do not think the entire responsibility is on mv-self.
Does the honorable senator contend that to grow coffee a duty °f 33 Per cent, and also a bounty are required?

am really not able to answer that question. That is one of the reasons why I wished to discuss these items from two independent points of view—first that of the Tariff, and secondly that of a bounties system. I asked that we should be allowed to deal with the Tariff first, in order that we might see how industries such as this would be affected by it, as distinct from a system of bounties. Under present conditions I cannot anticipate what the effect of the Tariff will be. We have, however, discarded that argument, and decided to have regard .only to the question of what new industries can be established in Australia with a reasonable chance of success, and whether the experts can show from absolute facts that those industries are already being carried 'on. On those lines the Committee bave already proceeded to vote thousands of pounds. My answer to Senator Millen's question is that I wanted to keep the questions of import duties and bounties separate. Amongst the many items in the schedule there is not one that can show a more reasonable chance of success than coffee.

(South Australia) [3.28].—It is refreshing to have, so much amusement thrown into our parliamentary labours, but I do not think it is very encouraging to reflect that a luminary of the law should talk for so long and not be able to make himself understood. I shall not try to emulate the last speaker. I do not believe in spreading myself, even if I could. When I was a boy in Old Scotland, I read a proverb of Solomon, to the effect that there is more hope for a fool than for a man who is wise in his own conceit. I ask Senator St. Ledger to think over that until the next sitting of the Senate. I have studied the report of the experts. They condemn this item, and I intend to vote against it.

(Queensland) [3.30].—Before I move the amendment whichi I outlined in my second:reading speech, I wish to refer once more to the question of the statistical position of coffee. I feel sure that Senator W. Russell is basing his opposition to the item on those two very unfortunate and, I think, very unjustified lines, in the report with reference to the world's production and consumption of coffee. In my second-reading speech, I pointed out that the production of Brazil has fallen nearly 50 per cent, since the date of the figures which the experts have quoted. In the case of food-stuffs, such as coffee, cocoa and sugar, it is not at all uncommon for the production in one year to be greater than the known consumption. For instance, the total production of cocoa throughout the world in 1906, was 260,000,000 lbs., but the total consumption was only 227,000,000 lbs. That may be taken as a very good reason why people in other parts of the world, or even in Australia should at once cease to cultivate cocoa. But, as a matter of fact, in the case of a great many food-stuffs, we find that, • whereas there is an over-production in one, two, or three years, the thing regulates itself in a decade or, it may be, a longer period. It is not uncommon, in connexion with such products as coffee, cocoa, and sugar, for a large amount of stock to be held im hand from one year to another —that is till there is a short production. Therefore, honorable senators need not pay a great deal of attention to the fact that in their report, the experts quote figures for 1901-2 as to the statistical position of coffee. I feel sure that those who have had an opportunity of tasting the Queensland coffee, which was served in the refreshment-room to-day, will admit that its quality is excellent. An officer, who is connected with the refreshment-room, has informed me that the price at which this coffee is quoted here and sold in Queensland is perfectly satisfactory as compared with the price of any other coffee which can be obtained here. Although the Queensland coffee-grower's are not sending down large quantities, still, the industry is on a fair road towards success. I believe that nothing can be said against the quality of the coffee of which samples have come under the attention of most honorable senators.
It is both cheaper and better than the majority of the imported coffees as sold.
I am glad to hear Senator Neild, who I believe, is a great authority on gastronomical delicacies, add his testimony to the qualities of Queensland coffee. I move—
speech.quote: That the word "Raw" be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words " as prescribed."
speech.para: The Minister may not desire to " see an alteration made, but I believe that the amendment will improve this line in the schedule, and meet the varied conditions under which coffee is hulled and pulped in different parts of Queensland. On a previous occasion, I pointed out that in some cases the farmers have their own pulping machines, and send the coffee up to a central factory or place which is provided with a hulling machine. • In other cases, they may both pulp and hull on. the ground. So far as I can see, it is impossible to provide in the schedule for tbe various cases. The clause, which gives power to make regulations, will enable the Government to deal with the conditions under which articles shall be produced. If we retain in the schedule the words " coffee, raw," it seems to me—-and I believe I am safe in saying that the Attomey:GeneraI holds the same view—that it will be somewhat difficult to. define what is meant by raw coffee. If, however, We adopt the words " coffee as prescribed," the regulations can be' framed in such a way that thev will apply to the various phases of hulling and pulping coffee, which occur throughout the very extensive areas from the south to nearly the north of Queensland, where coffee is grown in small or large quantities.
Does the honorable senator mean that the bounty is to be paid upon the production of coffee in the bean?
Yes. If it is to be paid upon the coffee after the bean has been hulled, undoubtedly it may go to the manufacturer.
That is what we do not want to happen.

Exactly. I believe it will be quite safe to allow the Department to frame the regulations in such a way as to meet the varying conditions under which coffee is hulled and pulped in different parts of Queensland. I am not speaking altogether on my own initiative. I have received a telegram— which I fear I have mislaid—from the chairman of the Buderim Coffee Growers' Association in South Queensland, in which he said that the bountv should be paid on parchment and not on hulled coffee, because the growers pulp the coffee and sell it in the parchment. I believe that my amendment will meet the views of every one.
What does the word "raw" in this item include?
The coffee bean itself.

(Western Australia) [3.40].—I regret that Senator St. Ledger is noc present, because I desire to congratulate him upon beinrr consistent in one thing, if in nothing else. I have not yet heard the honorable senator make a speech without first referring to the honorable - gentlemen on the opposite side, who he apparently concludes are always opposed to him. I hope that he does not include me within the category of his out-and-out supporters on this side, because I am not sitting here on account of my shade of politics, but as a matter of choice. I intend to oppose this item. I believe that there is a duty of about 50 per cent, on coffee, and when we add the freight, the' protection is brought up to about 7"! per cent. If the coffee industry cannot thrive with that protection, it ought to be abandoned. The grant of a bounty for the industry is only another phase of protection. It is proposed to spend, within the next eight vears, .£12,000 to foster an industrv which has enjoyed ample protection in the past, and had an excellent opportunity to establish itself. I believe it is thought that the best place in which to develop the industry in Australia is the Northern Territory. When I was there recently, I saw an abandoned coffee plantation near a place called Beatrice Hills, on the banks of the Adelaide River. We could see the. abandoned ploughs and other implements. An effort had been made to establish the industry- there when the Customs duty was even higher than it is now. I did expect that the senators from Queensland would make out a better case for this item than they have done. I looked particularly to Senator Chataway to supply facts and figures which would induce the Committee to vote for the item. . Throughout the consideration of this Bill, he has rendered valuable assistance to the Committee by putting forward facts and figures regarding various items, but to-day he has failed to prove the necessity or advisability of voting £12,000 to encourage the coffee industry. I want to compare the Queensland dutv on coffee with the Australian duty. Prior' to Federation, the Queensland duty on raw coffee was 4d. per lb., but under the Commonwealth Tariff the duty was fixed at 3d. Again, prior to Federation, the Queensland duty on kiln-dried coffee was 6d. per lb., but under the Federal Tariff the duty was fixed at .sd. Senator St. Ledger quoted a number of figures as to the area under cultivation from 1896 to 1905', showing that it had increased from 26 acres in 1896 to 335 acres in 1905. He proved to my satisfaction that even with that large protection, the industry did not thrive. We are asked to sanction the annual expenditure of £1,500 for the next eight years to encourage this industry. I shall not refer to the report of our own experts, which has been sufficiently quoted by Senator Henderson. But I propose to make a quotation from the report of a Conference held in the United States in 1902, to be found in the " Documents of the United States Senate, vol. 4, second session, 1902-1903." This report emphasizes the statement made by our own experts, that the trouble with the coffee industry is over-production.
CHATAWAY.—That is ancient history.

The honorable senator may think so, but he has failed to disprove any of the facts stated in the report of our experts, and I challenge him • to disprove the facts set out in the report of the American Conference.
In my second-reading speech I disproved all the figures in the experts' report.
The American Conference reported—
speech.quote: That although it is desirable that many improvements be introduced in the production .and commerce of coffee, the present crisis of that industry consists only in the lack of profit, and ruinous price paid for the commodity to the producer. That the principal cause of the low price which brings about the present crisis is the excess of the supply over the natural or normal demand.
speech.para: In the same volume there is a report of the Delegation from Ecuador, from which I quote the following—
speech.quote: In order to discharge the honorable commission of reporting upon the causes of the depreciation of coffee and the best means to be adopted for reaching a better commercial value, it were sufficient to reproduce the reasons so clear, so concise, so precise, given by the Commission, entitled " Associacao Commercial da Bahia," in its report of 21st March, 1901, addressed to the President of the " Directorio do Centro Commer. cial do Rio de Janeiro," namely, " that overproduction is the sole and principal cause of the great depreciation of coffee," as also " respecting any means for ameliorating this unfortunate situation it is evident that the onlj' thing to do consists .in establishing an equilibrium either by diminishing the output or by increasing the demand." Indeed, it is the increased output especially in Brazil that has brought about throughout the world the extraordinary and rapid depreciation that in so alarming a manner has caused the trade in this bean to suffer, especially since the 1S96-97 crop. That depreciation has reached to an average of 85 per cent., as compared only with the years 1891-1807. However, we will give some statistical figures as vouchers that bear out the simple words of the report quoted, as also that we ourselves insignificant contributors to the coffee out-turn are utterly incompetent to find a remedy; that Brazil, the paramount factor in that branch, has failed to. discover, in spite of the energetic efforts made to put off the economic disaster that is growing in that great Republic, namely, the drop in the price of its staple product of exchange. The statistical figures of the coffee output for the crop ending in June of the present year show a total of 20,000,000 bags, of which i5>439>00° come from Rio and Santos, and 4,561,000 bags from the other countries. The crop closing June, iqoi, showed an output of • 15,460,000 bags distributed thus—
speech.para: I shall not weary the Committee by reading the figures showing the distribution amongst the various countries. I have quoted from these reports to prove that it is ridiculous for us to attempt to develop the coffee industry in Australia with a paltry bounty of £1,500 a year for eight years.
The honorable senator does not think that the • amount proposed is enough ?

I do not, and if it were quadrupled it would not be sufficient to establish the industry in Australia at the present time, in view of the fact that Brazil is in a position to supply more coffee than is demanded by the world's consumption of the article.
But the honorable senator's figures are not correct. In my second-reading speech I gave later figures than he has quoted.

I was not present when the honorable senator made the speech to which he refers, but I am satisfied that there is ample proof that the Brazilian plantations aire quite able to meet the world's demand for coffee.
Granting that the honorable senator's statement is correct, the outside world can supply Australia with iron, but is that any reason why we should not establish the iron industry in the Commonwealth?
There is no analogy between the two industries.
We are all agreed on the White Australia policy; and is it not better that we should produce coffee with white people than that we should import coffee produced by black people?

It would be if we were in a position to do so, but I do not think that we can do so. I do not wish it to be understood that I am opposed to the bounties system. This, I think, is only the second item on the schedule that I have opposed. But I think that there should be some reasonable prospect shown that the expenditure of money in the form of bounties will be followed by some practical result. When speaking on the second reading of the Bill, I mentioned the fact that it' is possible to encourage in Australia an industry to which reference has been made by the Fisheries Conference, but to which the Government have paid no attention. So far, Ministers have vouschafed not one word of a reply to what has been said with regard to the' prospect of encouraging the sponge industry in Australia. Sponges-can be obtai ned on the coasts of Queensland, South Australia, and Western Australia. .1 read to the Senate a report which proved the soonges found on the-coast of Western Australia to be of a high commercial value.
I ask the honorable senator not to pursue that subject on this item.

I propose to move a . further amendment on the item when Senator Chataway's amendment has been dealt with. I intend to move that the words " Coffee, Raw," be left out, with a view to insert the word " Sponges."

I point out to the honorable senator that if he wishes to move that the word "Coffee" be struck out, he must get Senator Chataway to withdraw his amendment, because it would not be in order to move the omission of the word "Coffee" after the Committee had dealt with the word " raw."
Perhaps Senator Chataway will temporarily withdraw' his amendment to enable me to move the amendment I have suggested?
I am willing to withdraw my amendment temporarily. Amendment, by leave, withdrawn. Amendment (by Senator NEEDHAM) proposed—
speech.quote: That the words " Coffee, Raw," be left out, with a view to insert ia lieu thereof the word " Sponges."
speech.para: Progress reported.
Senate adjourned at 3.55 p.m.
